div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Sciendum quodque
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 1 (XXX).
. This is distinction 48 and the last of book 1 in which, after the Master showed in the preceding distinction the efficacy of the divine will, here he shows the concordance or consonance of the created will to the divine will And it is divided into two parts, for in the first place he shows that conformity in the thing willed is not evidence of the good will of the person, in the second place he shows that the good will of God is sometimes fulfilled through the depraved will of a human being or a will deformed by sin. The second part begins at,
Illud quoque
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 2 (XXX)
, etc.

The first is divided in two parts because in the first place he shows how we ought to conform our will to the divine will, in the second place through the Blessed Augustine he proves and concludes this. The second begins at,
unde Augustinus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 1 (XXX).
, etc.

And this second part is divided into four for in the first place he offers his intention regarding this matter, in the second place he is opposed by one objection, in the third place he offers the solution, in the fourth place he shows through this that someone is able to solve many questions. The second begins at,
sed adhuc opponitur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 2 (XXX).
. The third begins at,
ad quodam respondentes
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 2
. The fourth at,
ex quo solvitur
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 3 (XXX).
. And this is the division of the present distinction, etc.

div.head: Question
Whether it is the case that the act of created will is correct without conformity to the divine will
div.p: Whether it is the case that the act of created will is correct without conformity to the divine will

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p:
That not because it is not the case that the created intellect can be correct and itself not in conformity with the divine intellect, therefore the same goes for the act of the will, etc.
The consequence is clear for a similar reason namely because the divine intellect is the rule of anything true and correct, otherwise when the intellect assents to a false opinion it would not err, which is false.

In the second place, no act is correct unless it is graciously accepted by the divine will, therefore. The consequence is clear because no act is just or correct and accepted unless it conforms to the divine will. The antecedent is clear in
Romans 9 ,
non est volentis neque currentis sed Dei
Ad Romanos 9:16. , etc.

In the third place, it is not the case that the divine created will has rectitude without its own likeness or conformity to the divine will, therefore. The consequence is clear since the correct act of the will presupposes and includes rectitude. And the antecedent is clear through the saying of
Augustine in Contra Faustum
which says
sin is something said, done, or desired against the law or the will of God
Augustinus, Contra Faustum XXII, 27 (XXX).
. This is confirmed because the divine will is not conforming to the created, therefore neither is the converse the case. The consequence holds because relative comparisons are said to be converses.

In opposition, it is argued that licitly one is able to will what God does not will, therefore this is also the case for an act, etc. The consequences is clear, and the antecedent is found in the
Master
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
, when he introduces,
Augustine, in the Enchiridion , where he speaks about
the good son, licitly willing that his father should live, whom God will should die
, indeed knowing that God does not will that he lives.

div.head: Conclusion 1
div.p:
First conclusion: though for the rectitude and certitude of the created intellect its conformity to the divine intellect with respect to the known object is required, nevertheless to the rectitude of the created will its conformity to the divine will with respect to the willed object is not always achieved. The first part is clear through
Augustine, in his book on immortality, chapter 18 ,
if indeed the truth we speak it through that by which all things are true
Augustinus, De immortalitate animae, I, c. 12
. This is confirmed by reason because, if not, then it follows that it would be the case that the created intellect would truly and certainly know somethning and God would not know it. The consequent is impossible since the divine intellect is the idea and cognitive and representative exemplar of anything which is true. And the consequence is clear because, if the divine and human intellect understand the same object under the same formal ratio, then it follows that there is conformity in the object known. The second part is clear through
Augustine, in the Enchiridion, where it was mentioned about regarding the son, etc.
Augustinus, Enchiridion xxx
.

First corollary: just as one rectitude exceeds another rectitude, so not every rectitude has the same latitude. The first part is clear because moral rectitude exceeds natural rectitude. Against, an immeasurable rectitude exceeds a created rectitude. Again, uncreated liberty exceeds angelic liberty, and angelic liberty exceeds human liberty. The second part is clear because it follows, one rectitude exceeds another, therefore not all rectitudes have the same perfectional latitude. The consequences is clear because, if they were to have the same perfection, then none of them would exceed another with respect to perfection.

Second corollary: it is the case that something is morally deficient and desires objectively that which God wishes. This is clear through the Master and Augustine in this distinction because God wishes well and with a good will that a person wishes badly and with a bad will.

Third corollary: it is the case that the created mind is materially and objectively in conformity with the divine mind and at the same time is habitually non-conforming to the same divine will or it is the case that something is in conformity with the divine will and not actually non-conforming.
The first part is clear since the Jews were wishing the death of Christ with a bad will which God was willing with a good will. This is clear just as the preceding was. The second is clear because it is the case that some have the habit of grace or charity and yet do not
produce a meritorious act.

div.head: Conclusion 2
div.p: Second conclusion: it is the case that two wills are not in conformity with one another and at the same time the they are in conformity with one and the same thing. This is clear because the angel of the Persians was wishing to resist the angel of Daniel working for the liberation of the Israelite people in 12 days as is clear in the book of Daniel, and nevertheless it is the case that both of these wills are conforming to the will of God. Again, Abraham wished to sacrifice his son and the angel did not will this, indeed the angel prohibited it, and yet each one had their will in conformity with the divine will because they were willing that which God was willing for them to will otherwise they would have been sinning, which should not be said.

First corollary: though the pilgrim will that acts in deformity with right reason is itself sinning and demeritorious, nevertheless the will that a will that acts in conformity to right reason does not always imply that this will itself is just or meritorious. The first part is clear when speaking about adult pilgrims both because someone who acts against conscience or the dictate of reason helps build Gehenna and because acting rightly or meritoriously means conforming oneself to right reason according to the all the proper and required circumstances which are enumerated by the
Philosopher, in book 2 of the Ethics
Aristoteles
, therefore someone not in conformity with right reason is acting badly and sinning mortally. The second part is proved because someone existing in mortal sin is able to will or to choose a contrite heart and thus regarding many other circumstances and dictates is able to conform itself to right reason, therefore not just any conformity of the will to right reason implies that the will is just. Again, someone is able to wish to give alms and to give de facto to do many good works conforming to right reason

The second corollary: though no assent elicited from what is purely natural is meritorious, nevertheless true assent is able to be elicited from what is purely natural. The first part is clear because
We are not sufficient of ourselves, as of ourselves from
The second part is clear from the
preceding corollary
because, if while in mortal sin it is possible to have true assent and a judgment conforming to right reason, it follows a fortior that someone existing in pure nature using reason while not otherwise impeded is able to make such a judgement.

Third corollary: some will having been conformed to the dictate of right reason is unjust and deformed through sin or thus some will, which is deformed through guilt, is not deformed with respect to any right dictate or right reason. Again, the will is able to be deformed without there being some judgment actually in the intellect.

div.head: Conclusion 3
div.p:
Third conclusion: moral conformity or rectitude of the human will to the divine will consists in willing or nilling (nolle) that which the highest beauty will ought to be willed or nilled I say ought to be on account of the likeness because as long as a person does this chosen work God wishes that this person wishes this, and nevertheless without such willing the will is able to be in conformity with the divine will because the divine will does not wish that this ought to be willed because then it would sin if it did not will that this is so, which is false. The conclusion is clear through
Anselfm, in his book De similitudinibus, in chapter 3 , where he says that
we ought not always will what God wills but we ought to will this which God will for us to will
Anselmum, De similitudinis c. 3
. Again, through
Augustine, on Psalmo 31 ,
those right of heart are those who direct the heart according to the will of God.

First corollary: it is not always required for the moral and just rectitude of the will that one will what they know without ambiguity that the highest beauty and certainty wills, which is opposed to
Thomas of Argentina
Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 47-48, q. 1, a. 4 (Genoa 1585, 124v)
. This is clear because having removed the Breviary I know without a doubt that God wills that I destroy it, and nevertheless God is able to make it so that I do not wish this. The minor is proved because licitly I am to wish to have the Breviary and to wish to not have it sent away or to not send it away lest I cannot perform the prayers of the hours since I do not have another breviary.

Second corollary: though the opposite of the divine is able to be will licitly by a created will, nevertheless anything rightly and justly willed is the object of the divine will. The first part is clear from what was said. The second part is proved because whatever is justly willed by a created will God wishes that this will wills but whatever God wishes this just willing is the object of the divine will, therefore.

Third corollary: it is the case that some have a right will and earn merit and yet their own will is in some mode in deformity with the divine will, which is opposed to the opinion of
Gregory XXX
and
Hugolinus
XXX . This is clear because according to all doctors anyone ought to will what God wishes them to will, but there is a possible case where God wishes that someone will the opposite of that which God wills, therefore. From these things the affirmative response to the question is clear.

div.head: Objections
div.p:
Against the
first conclusion , it is argued thus, the human and divine intellect are infinitely distant and dissimilar, therefore between them there is no conformity, and consequently the conclusion is false. The first consequence is clear because between infinitely dissimilar things no conformity seems to be possible. And the second consequence is clear because no one is obliged to what is absolutely impossible.

In the second place, against the
first corollary
, the definition of what is right is equally suitable to all right things, therefore one right thing is not more right than another thing, nor does one rectitude exceed another, and thus the corollary is false.

In the third place, one straight line is not straighter than another, therefore neither is one understanding (intellectus) more correct than another. And it is similarly able to be argued about the will as it seems the rectitude consists in indivisibles.

In the fourth place against the other corollaries, it follows that it would be the case that Socrates sins, and nevertheless he wills in whatever manner God wills that he will. The consequent is false because then it would be the case that Socrates sins and God wills that Socrates will whatever God himself wills, and thus God wishes that Socrates sins, which should not be said.
In the fifth place, if someone wills however God wills for them to will and wishes that this is not a sin, then he does not wish to sin and consequently does not sin.

In the sixth place, no one sins by totally conforming their will to the divine will, but someone willing whatever God wills that they will is totally conforming their will to the divine will, therefore.

Against the
second conclusion
, no created will is able to be in conformity with the divine will, therefore etc. The antecedent is proved because, if this were true, the conversion would follow namely that the divine will would be in conformity with the created will because the relatives of a comparison are said to be converting. The consequent is false, therefore.

In the second place, something is willed by God to which nothing is able to be in conformity without guilt, therefore. The antecedent is proved because God willed that Christ be killed, and he was not able to be killed except unjustly, therefore the one willing that Christ be killed did so unjustly and in an evil (bad) way.

In the third place against the
third corollary
, it is argued from the determination of the council, where it is said,
both are gifts of God to know what we ought to do and to desire to do it
Concilium Carthaginense (418), canon 4 (Denzinger, Enchiridion (1911), p. 48, num. 104)
.

In the fourth place, it is argued through the
Blessed Augustine, in book III of the De libero arbitrio, in chapter 39 ,
the human being fails to what is right
Augustinus, De libero arbitrio III, 18, 52 (PL 32)
. And one is not freed from this penalty except through a gift of God, therefore a human being is not able to follow a command in conformity to right reason without charity.

In the fifth place, it is argued through
the same author, in book I of his Retractions, in chapter 9
to the misery of the justly damned pertains the ignorance which all people suffer
Augustinus, Retractionum I, 9, 6
, therefore ignorance of what is being done belongs to every mortal sin.

Again the
third conclusion , it is argued that, if this were the case, then it would follow that someone would be obligated to will that they do not exist in the state of grace. The consequent is false because then the will would be obligated to will its own lack of rectitude. And the consequence is clear regarding one who is sinning and falling from guilt into grace, and indeed conversely falling from grace into guilt because one knows that God wishes that they be deprived of grace.

In the second place, if it was revealed to Socrates that he must be perpetually damned, it follows that he would be obliged to will his own damnation. The consequent is false because then he would licitly not be able to pray to God for his own salvation or to choose it, and thus he would be compelled to despair and sin.

In the third place, God wills that every pilgrim keeps his commands out of charity, but the one sinning mortally according to the measure by which he sins or is in the state of mortal sin is not able to keep his commands in this way and nevertheless he is not obliged to do the impossible, therefore he is not obliged to will what he knows God will him to will.

Fourth against the
first corollary , it is argued through the
Gloss on that Psalm, non adhaesit mihi cor pravum , the depraved and distorted heart
is had by one who does not will what God wills
. Again, in the same place,
the will of God is the rule to which it is necessary that we conform ourselves
XXX
.

In the fifth place against the
second corollary
, if this were the case, then it would follow that God would will opposites and contraries at the same time. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because that which I will is the object of the divine will, but anything that is the object of the divine will God wills, there God wills the opposite, which is what was proposed.

In the sixth place against the
third corollary
, it follows that someone would be obligated to will against the eternal law of God. The consequent is false because everyone will thus is sinning. The consequence is clear through
Augustine, Contra Faustum 22 , saying,
the eternal law or ratio or the divine will
Augustinus, Contra Faustum xxx
, therefore. This is the argument of
Hugolinus
Hugolinus de Urbe Veteri, xxx .

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first , I say that conformity is two-fold, one is natural or a proportion of natural co-measure, the other is a kind of disposition and imitation. When speaking about the first the antecedent is conceded, but the consequence is denied. When speaking about the second, the antecedent is denied.

To the second
, the consequence is denied. The objection is clear from the sorts of things undergoing intension and remission

In the second place, it would be able to be said when denying the antecedent because just as the reasoning is more suitable to an angel, so etc. To the confirmation which is second, it is said that
one straight line is not more straight than another
, therefore. Here it is said that, just as a straight line of gold is different than a straight line of iron, so it is in the proposed. But it would be able to objected because this does not solve the argument because, though in this case there is not an equally good rectitude, nevertheless there is in this case an equal rectitude in the being of rectitude. To this it is said that there is not a similarity between the case of straight lines and the right dictates because the fact that a line to be straight does not come from something extrinsic to which more and more is able to be in conformity, as is the case of a correct dictate, therefore the cases are not the same, and therefore the consequences should be denied. Again, it is noted that, just as an indivisible ternary is not a ternary and similarly a binary, nevertheless the ternary exceeds a binary,
so a rectitude consists in something indivisible, and yet nevertheless one exceeds the other and one rectitude is a perfection.

To the fourth
, the consequent is conceded because regarding the deformity of Socrates God has a non-willing, and nevertheless he has a will that he give alms and also that Socrates wills this, and when the falsity of the consequent is proved
because then it would be the case that Socrates
etc., this consequence is denied, for it does not follows that Socrates wishes however God wills that he wills, therefore God wills that Socrates wills however he himself wills. The reason is because with respect to his own deformed will God has no will.

To the fifth
, it is said that God does not will that Socrates sins, even when it is granted that Socrates will sin, nevertheless always speaking about the will of what is pleasing, not the will of the sign. The reason is because with respect to wicked things God does not have a will or non-will, as is clear through the
Master, in distinction 46
Lombardus, Sent I, d. 46, c. 7
.

To the sixth
, the minor is denied because conformity of the human will to the divine does not stand fully in these two things, namely that Socrates wills whatever he knows that God wills and whatever he wills that he wills.

To the first against the second conclusion
, the antecedent is denied regarding the conformity of a disposition and imitation. And to the proof, the consequent is able to be conceded.

In the second place, it is able to be said that in related things, which are disposed to one another as cause and effect, it is not necessary that if the effect is similar to the cause that conversely the cause is similar to the effect. Nor is it necessary that just what is right is in conformity to its own rule that a rule is in conformity with what is completely right.

To the second
, the antecedent is denied. To the proof, it is said that it is not the same for Christ to be killed and Christ to be injustly killed. Again, it is said that I am able to will that Christ was obedient to the Father and posited those things those things which are meritorious for our salvation, and nevertheless I ought not to will that the Jews killed Christ. Therefore, though it was not possible that Christ be killed except unjustly, nevertheless of the pure one and saints I am able to will his passion and that of other saints, as is shown by the
Master in this distinction
Lombard, Sent. I, d. xxx
. And thus in the killing of Christ there are distinct objects, namely the good of virtue in Christ and the evil of the will in the Jews. But against this response Hugolinus objects because, if he was not able to be killed except unjustly, it follows that man is not able to be redeemed unless someone committed a new sin. Here the consequence is denied, though man was not able to be redeemed through the death of Christ unless someone unjustly killed Christ, nevertheless he was able to redeem man in a other way than through his death, but this material pertains to the third book.

To the third
, when it is argued through authority for the understanding of those things and of those people, it is said the claim that the act of assent is correct is able to be taken in three ways, in one mode as being natural or false, in the second mode as being moral and virtuous, in the third mode as being supernatural and meritorious. Therefore by following the opinion of our Doctor Gregory about a morally good act, it is able to be said that the authorities ought to be understood in the second and third modes. Otherwise it would be able to be said by following another opinion that it ought to be understood in the third mode, namely that such an assent or such a command is not able, from nature, to have meritorious rectitude. And this is true. Through this the response to
the fourth argument
and
the fifth argument
are clear which are authorities of Augustini.

To the first against the third conclusion
,
Master Thomas de Argentina
says the fact that man is not in grace is not absolutely willed, but is willed under a condition, and when man is able to will the opposite of this condition licitly he also licitly able to will the opposite of what was willed. Thus in the proposed, God wills to remove grace from Socrates. If he sins now sins it is certain that it was licit for Socrates, indeed he was obligated, to will the opposite of the condition and consequently the opposite of what was willed. In line with this
is
Gregory, in this distinction
who says,
the one sinning and knowing the will ough to wish and it ought to be pleasing to him that God removes grace from him beacuse it is just and pleasing to God, and nevertheless it does not follow from this that he ought to wish that he is not in grace because this consequently implies that for some amount of time he wishes to not be in the state of grace
.
Hugolinus, in this last distinction
Hugolinus de Urbe Veteri, xxx
speaks otherwise, saying that,
in such a removal of grace two things should be considered, first namely
to be deprived of grace as an accident is to the mind or adhering to or existing in the will, and is a merely penal, and the other is the indignity of grace and the repugnance to it, and this is a kind formal and fleeable sin.
. The first there as it prescinds from guilt he is able to will licitly and justly, but the second, namely the indignity ought to be fleed from and not willed. In another way it is able to be said that God is able to will that I be deprived of grace, and nevertheless he does not will this, that I will or do not will that I will this, and in this way such a person is able to licitly not will this.

To the second
, it is responded just as it was to the preceding by denying the consequence because with such a revelation it would be the case that God would not wish Socrates to wish for himself to be damned.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that when taking the word damnation for the misery of the penalty positively without inclusion of guilt that such a person is obliged to will this because this is just. But when taking it for the misery of guilt or for the latitude of the indignity of glory, in this case one is not obliged to wish for their own damnation.

Ad tertiam
, it is said in the first place according to some that it is not repugnant that someone at the same time both loves God exists outside of charity.
In the second place, it is said that many is able to oblige himself to something impossible, at least secundum quid and this is from his own guilt.
In the third place, the whole argument would be able to be conceded because I am not always obliged to wish what I know God wishes.

To the fourth
, it is said that the
Gloss
ought to be understood in the following way, namely whoever does not wish in such a way as they ought to wish.

In the second place, I say that the
Gloss
should not be understood just as it is because other a newly baptized child would have a distorted heart because he does not wish what God wishes. To the confirmation, it is said that God does not wish to that rule, which is the divine will, in the manner stated in the third conclusion.

To the fifth
, the consequence is denied for which it should be known something can be an object of the divine will in two ways, in the first mode in itself, in the second mode in its own act. But that which I will is not the object of the divine will in itself immediately but in its own act, namely in my own willing. But it is not necessary that with respect to every such thing it is a proper act or, if it is an act, then it will not be the opposite of the act with respect to the act of the opposite object, therefore the argument does not conclude.

To the sixth
, the consequence is denied. To the proof, it is said that it does not follow that, if am obliged to make my will unconformed to the divine will with respect to something willed, therefore I am obliged to make my will unconformed to the divine will. Whence a similar consequence is denied by
Gregory in this matter and this distinction in hac materia et distinctione
Gregorius, I, d. xxx ,
namely this, I am obliged to will the privation of grace in this instance, therefore I am obliged to will the privation of grace. Similarly it is said that it does not follow, I am obliged to will the opposite of the divine will with respect to this willed thing, therefore I will be obliged to will the opposite of the divine will. Again,
Hugolinus
wishing to resolve the arguments of volens solvere rationes Deum
Domini Alphonsi
says,
it is not the same for you to wish something deformed in this willed thing that God wishes and for you to will in deformity with the divine will out of sheer pleasure
.
To the principle arguments it is clear what should be said through the preceding arguments.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p:
Sciendum quoque
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, xxx
, etc.
The first conclusion of this 48th and last distinction of the first book of the Sentences:
that the will of person wishing that something happens that God wills sometimes is evil, and when willing something other than what God wills is sometimes good
. The examples are clear in the text. and last.

Second conclusion: that
the good will of God is sometimes fulfilled through an evil will of man.
. For God wished with a good will the death of Christ which the Jews carried out for him with an evil will.

Third conclusion: that
the entire Trinity wished that Christ would suffer, nevertheless it did not wish the Jews would kill him because it willed the penalty of the crucifixion, but it did not will the guilt of the Jews, and nevertheless it did not willed against it because if it had willed against it would not have happened
.

Fourth conclusion: that
it was pleasing to the holy men that Christ would be killed considering our redemption and the fulfillment of the divine will, but it was not pleasing when considering the torment of his punishment
.

Fifth conclusion: that
man is able to will and nil the sufferings of the saints with a good will
. For with a good will they wish the passion of Christ who they suffering with and from compassion they do not wish it. But whoever was wishing this so that his crown would be increased was wishing this, etc.
